name: fatty alcohol production, petrochemical | fatty alcohol | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/2571/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of fatty alcohol from pertrochemical. ;Technology is based on European production in the mid 90'. Two production processes were considered: Ziegler process and Oxo process. For the dataset it was assumed according to literature sources a mix of 82% of fatty alcohols produced with the Oxo process and 18% produced by the Ziegler process.;In each step examined, the material and energy input as well as the emissions to air and water and the produced waste are from literature sources. Water consumption and infrastructure are estimation. Transport is calculated based on literature sources.;Production system of fatty alcohols from petrochemical:;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From reception of precursors ethylene, n-olefin, natural gas, crude oil at the factory gate.

This activity ends with 1 kg of fatty alcohol. This dataset includes material and energy input, water consumption, infrastructure, transport, production of waste and emissions for the production of fatty alcohol out of petropchemical.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data based on the European n-olefins production
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Average technology typical for European production conditions in the mid 90s. //Comment added during dataset update:// the petrochemical route has been designated as modern, since it has the good ability to change capacity with changes in demand compared to most oleochemical raw materials (with palm oil as an exception).;For the production out of petrochemical resources, two main routes exist:;1) Ziegler process: this process is a catalytic process involving as catalyst triethylaluminium.  After a hydrogenation of the catalyst, ethylene is inserted into the aluminium-carbon bond of this molecule to build up the carbon chain. This step is then followed by a growth reaction of the aluminium alkyls to aluminium alcoholates by oxidation with air. These are then subsequently hydrolysed to alcohols, as shown in the process steps listed.;Flow diagram of the Ziegler process for the production of petrochemical fatty alcohols:;The different process reactions: Hydrogenation [1], ethylation [2], growth reaction [3], oxidation [4] and final hydrolysis [5];2) Oxo process: this process constitutes a hydroformylation in which long chain olefins are reacted with hydrogen and carbon monoxide. An intermediate aldehyde is formed, which is subsequently reduced by hydrogen. ;Flow diagram of the oxo process for the production of petrochemical fatty alcohols:;Reference:;Noweck K. (2001) Fatty Alcohols. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Sixth Edition, June 2001
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: data out of ECOSOL study of European Surfactant Industry. Common translation rules used, reported in Chemical report (Althaus et al. 2003). This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography RER. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
Fatty alcohols are aliphatic alcohols with chain lengths between C6 and C22: 
CH3(CH2)nCH2OH (n=4-20)
They are predominantly linear and monohydric and can be saturated or have one or more double bonds. Alcohols with a carbon chain length above C22 are referred to as wax alcohols. Diols with chain lengths exceeding C8 are regarded as substituted fatty alcohols. The character of fatty alcohols (primary or secondary, linear or branched, saturated or unsaturated) is determined by the manufacturing process and the raw material used. Fatty alcohols and their derivatives are used in polymers, surfactants, oil additives and cosmetics and have many specialty uses.
While saturated fatty alcohols up to dodecanol are clear colorless liquids, the next higher homologues are soft materials. Saturated alcohols crystallize in a nearly orthorhombic lattice and all of them have a lower specific density than water. While lower members have a characteristic odor, higher fatty alcohols are odorless. The boiling as well as the melting points increase uniformly with the chain lengh and are both significantly higher compared with hydrocarbons having the same number of carbon atoms. Suitable solvents therefore are common organic solvents - i.e. petroleum ether, lower alcohols, diethyl ether. Concerning the solubility in water, only hexanol and octanol show some solubility - all higher fatty alcohols are immiscible with water.
Fatty alcohols are mainly used as derivatives. In Western Europe only 5% of the production is used directly and 95% is used as intermediates. Major property of fatty alcohols is the amphiphilic character. Therefore, surfactants account for 70-75% of total fatty alcohol production. They can be used in detergents, emulsions, cosmetic creams, lotions, or as lubricants.
